Ziege Zudj Gud goad
ğ’ˆ§ ğ’šğ’• maÅ¡â‚‚uzud â€¢maÅ¡â‚‚zud mastgoat breed-goat

The wild bezoar ibex of the Zagros Mountains is the likely original ancestor of probably all domestic goats today.[6]

Neolithic farmers began to herd wild goats primarily for easy access to milk and meat, as well as to their dung, which was used as fuel; and their bones, hair, and sinew were used for clothing, building, and tools.[1] The earliest remnants of domesticated goats dating 10,000 years before present are found in Ganj Dareh in Iran. Goat remains have been found at archaeological sites in Jericho, Choga Mami,[8] Djeitun, and Ã‡ayÃ¶nÃ¼, dating the domestication of goats in Western Asia at between 8,000 and 9,000 years ago. The first arrival of goat herders in China is attested at the Shimao site.
The genetic goat haplogroups A,B,C,D,E split very early, but mostly only A is found in early Anatolia, while A,B,C reached China and D is prevalent in India.

Historically, goat hide has been used for water and wine bottles in both traveling and transporting wine for sale. It has also been used to produce parchment.

Proto-Indo-Europeans probably did not have a word for â€˜goatâ€™. This follows from the fact that all â€œIndo-European terms for â€˜goatâ€™ for the most part have areal distributionsâ€ (Gamkrelidze/Ivanov
1995: 500). Mallory and Adams (2006: 104) reconstruct five goat words for PIE, h 11
viz. *dig-, *buÇµ-, *h2eiÇµ- (Geiss), *h2eÇµ- and *kapr- , but all of these reconstructions, except perhaps *bhuÇµ- (Bock), turn out to be post-PIE regionalisms with roots that defy the rules of PIE phonology.

PIE *H4eyÄŸ- â€˜goatâ€™ (a well-established root) Geiss reverse
IEW 13 *aiÄŸ- Hurrian aigalluhi

It was suggested by MÃ¶ller (1911: 128) that the source of goat OCS koza is Semitic *gadiÌ¯ - â€˜goatâ€™, cf. Arab. gadyu , Hebr. g Î´Ä«, Berb. agayd. The same etymon, however, was more appropriately linked to **ghaid- by Illich-Svitych (1964: 3), who assumed borrowing at the Proto-Indo-European level. This view was embraced by Levin (1995: 115â€“9) and the occidentalist Bernal (2006, III: 101â€“2), the latter arguing that the languages in which it occurs, i.e. Germanic and Latin, were too distant from South-West Asia to have adopted it individually after the disintegration of the Proto-Indo-European unity. To Vennemann, however, exactly this dialectal isolation meant the confirmation of his view that Northern Europe was colonized from the Western Mediterranean by Semitic sea-farers (e.g. 1995: 90; 2003a: 250â€“2, 615). Both hypotheses are actually defendable, but Vennemannâ€™s scenario implies that cattle breeding spread to North West Europe through sea-bound colonization along the Atlantic coast, which is contradicted by the archaeological evidence.

Diakonovâ€™s suggestion (1985: 132) that both Italo-Germanic
Non-Indo-European root nouns in Germanic: evidence in support of the Agricultural Substrate Hypothesis *ghaid- and PSem. *gadiÌ¯ - originate from a third source, which ultimately may be connected to the aforementioned synonyms *aiÌ¯ diÌ¯ - and *kÄÌ† Çµ(h)-. In this context, it is important to consider similar words for â€˜goatâ€™ and â€˜billy goatâ€™ in the Caucasian languages, e.g. Adyge ÄÄa â€˜he-goatâ€™, Dargwa (Akushi) Ê•eÅ¾a â‹ (Chi- rag) Ê•aÄ:a (Witzel 2004: Â§2.3). Most plausibly, the â€˜goatâ€™ word filtered through the old continuum of agricultural and cattle breeding cultures that had expanded into Europe from the East in the millennia preceding the arrival of the Indo-Europeans.
